text: Yeah I agree. I do believe in mixing it up, and that's the plan for the moment. What I don't want is them to create tons of TOFU content which I then have to rewrite because the TOV is off or the content is not relevant...

text:
That's WILD! So sorry you got ripped off like that.

The way our content strategy process works is that we create a calendar based on your desired posting cadence for 12 months. If you're posting 10x/month, we would give you 120 primary keywords (and all their variants, usually 2-5 per KW).

The reason for that is basically to keep things straightforward with a calendar that's easy to understand. :woman-shrugging::skin-tone-2: But I do love <@U01P13NTGG6>’ approach for a more strictly keyword research approach, not necessarily trying to fit the keywords into a calendar.

text: Is anyone here an SEO/Backlink expert? We’re thinking of paying a contractor to go and leave comments on other blogs to point back to our website and a new page we want to increase rankings on. A few things I’ve read say that’s kind of a dead strategy and the girl we’ve talked to said she does 100-200 word comments which seems high but now I’ mwondering if that is because she would be writing/leaving quality comments versus a one-off spammy type. but is this indeed even worthwhile? Are there any better more current backlink strategies out there?

elements.text: Is anyone here an SEO/Backlink expert? We’re thinking of paying a contractor to go and leave comments on other blogs to point back to our website and a new page we want to increase rankings on. A few things I’ve read say that’s kind of a dead strategy and the girl we’ve talked to said she does 100-200 word comments which seems high but now I’ mwondering if that is because she would be writing/leaving quality comments versus a one-off spammy type. but is this indeed even worthwhile? Are there any better more current backlink strategies out there?

text: Most comment sections are nofollow so this is generally considered a waste-of-time back linking strategy. You’d likely be better off working with a content/PR agency to create content that gets links and to drive mentions in the news/publications to drive those links. My two cents!

elements.text: Most comment sections are nofollow so this is generally considered a waste-of-time back linking strategy. You’d likely be better off working with a content/PR agency to create content that gets links and to drive mentions in the news/publications to drive those links. My two cents!

text: Another option would be to respond to quality HARO requests

text: hi Jennifer, yeah it's good question my two cents is that a blog commenting like you mention is kind of dead now maybe at one point it did work but in this day and age it's just not going to move the needle for you anymore. Instead of what I was suggest is a trying a couple of different link building strategies. 1) Link Reclamation - basically you search for websites that mentioned your brand, company, employees without a link and simply reach out asking for a link 2) HARO - I also recommend using Haro to build more PR style links 3) Competitor Link Building - with this one take your top 3-5 competitors and run them through ahrefs or semrush and take a look what links you can replicate and start picking them off one by one

elements.text: hi Jennifer, yeah it's good question my two cents is that a blog commenting like you mention is kind of dead now maybe at one point it did work but in this day and age it's just not going to move the needle for you anymore. text:
Agreed with Carolyn that comment linking should be avoided, as Google hates that sort of thing.

You can hire an agency, or I also work for a company that creates data journalism on brands' behalf and then distributes it through a newswire.

People often hire out for this sort of thing because it's a lot of work to do internally, BUT if you have great internal data or high-quality researchers/writers, you could put something together that appeals to your target audience and try to build links that way.

text:
Hey <@UUURB3M19>, we're fairly down on intentional backlinking and don't recommend it to clients very much anymore. Not that it can never work, but.

First of all, it's so time-consuming to get a helpful backlink, and there are other things it usually makes sense to prioritize (e.g. content creation and other forms of distribution). On top of that, Google doesn't like what it calls "link schemes". Lastly, "inferred backlinks" are becoming much more important, and those don't require you to ask.

There are exceptions where you might want to pursue, but in general we think other things are more important, depending of course on your goals and situation.

We just wrote about this in the newsletter this morning, I'll link you to it here :slightly_smiling_face: <https://www.ercule.co/newsletter/10>

attachments.title: #10: Cue the dramatic hamster – Ercule
attachments.text: Backlinks vs. inferred links, Google changing your page titles on SERP, Gravy and cold email schooling.

elements.text: Hey

, we're fairly down on intentional backlinking and don't recommend it to clients very much anymore. Not that it can never work, but.

First of all, it's so time-consuming to get a helpful backlink, and there are other things it usually makes sense to prioritize (e.g. content creation and other forms of distribution). On top of that, Google doesn't like what it calls "link schemes". Lastly, "inferred backlinks" are becoming much more important, and those don't require you to ask.

There are exceptions where you might want to pursue, but in general we think other things are more important, depending of course on your goals and situation.

We just wrote about this in the newsletter this morning, I'll link you to it here

text: What percentage of monthly search volume do you think is SEOs searching the keyword? It's an honest question I've had for awhile.

elements.text: What percentage of monthly search volume do you think is SEOs searching the keyword? It's an honest question I've had for awhile.

text: (Especially for lower search volume, competitive B2B terms)

elements.text: (Especially for lower search volume, competitive B2B terms)

text: This is a great question. I don’t have a guess at the answer.

elements.text: This is a great question. I don’t have a guess at the answer.

text: Not a lot. Unless it’s a super specific, long-tail keyword that only a few people would search for. Most SEOs use tools, track hundreds or thousands of KWs, and don’t Google their individual keywords for their data.

elements.text: Not a lot. Unless it’s a super specific, long-tail keyword that only a few people would search for. Most SEOs use tools, track hundreds or thousands of KWs, and don’t Google their individual keywords for their data.

text:
+1 on what Brendan said. We didn’t do any backlink building for years at Close, and our growth is almost exclusively based on organic traffic from content.

(We’ve recently started a bit just because there’s a lot of low-hanging fruit and we want to see how much it can move the needle on some selected, priority pages that are hard to attract organic backlinks to.)

But in general, I’m a big believer that it’s better to invest all that time, effort, and money into creating remarkable content, rather than backlink building.

elements.text:

But in general, I’m a big believer that it’s better to invest all that time, effort, and money into creating remarkable content, rather than backlink building.
